content: No capital G in the test cases, but in the validators is breaking everyone's neck.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: putting the words in boxes is not fun,
but hey, at least it is nice string manipulation practice.
I would want to have some shorter test cases especially for reverse mode. It's tedious to look at long lines in the IDE since you can't see it all at once.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: hard one, but atypical. I tested several options (regexp, split+foreach+includes), and it can be done in 5 minutes.

the description and the tests cover the edge cases

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I liked the Reverse mode as it is a simple mechanism (even for beginners) but still have to think about that.
Once you get it, the coding part is quite easy (5min is ok for me). 
Also there is a lot to do for Shortest mode. 
The description is clear and I didn't see any problem in the test cases.
Approved!

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: It is a fun and unusual puzzle but I am not sure if it is solvable in 5 minutes considering you have to make a border around the emphasised words and the spacing is also something you can't mess up otherwise the solution would not be accepted.

Hello Lisa, looks nice but some issues with results such as "eggs," and "egg". I would consider that "eggs" should be the correct answer.  So punctuation marks should be removed to avoid this issue. 

Also the issue of "charming.)" where ")" is considered part of the word.

Hi MadMax --

Thanks for the feedback.

I realize that punctuation is a problem/issue, that is not easily addressed, but I wanted to keep the Clash simple (doable in 5-15 minutes) by Not including that as something to address.  Therefore I put in the Notes section "Any punctuation next to a word counts as part of that word"

Do you think there is a better way?

Thanks for the feedback.  

I do realize it's "on the harder side" of the range of clashes, but I do believe many can solve in 5 minutes, and most can solve in 15.  I have tried to keep it simple in that punctuation does not need to be addressed at all; it just counts as part of the word.  And handling spacing is just a matter of using a built-in trim-function.

(Just as a side note, I have never understood why clashes have a 15 minute time limit, but a submission has to be solvable in 5 minutes.)
Thank you !!
Thanks !!!

Right, good point.
I have now reversed Test1 with Validator1.
That makes Test1 much shorter and easier to digest.

I also chopped off part of Test1
Thanks for the approval :)

Thanks for the feedback; I hadn’t noticed that.  

I have now swapped test4 with validator4, so that should solve it.  Sorry for the headache, and thanks for letting me know.

It didn't fully solve it FWIW, since "Georgian" contains both a lowercase `g` and an uppercase `G`.

So lowercase-only solutions would pass the tests with 100% even so, without clearing up the ambiguity. I fixed it now by rephrasing it (but the quote is not so accurate to the actual book anymore tho).

I've reinstated the link at the end of the Goal section, adding the phrase "with a small modification." I don't believe it should be removed entirely.

Additionally, since the current instructions specify that words containing "G" or "g" should be enclosed in a box, changing "Georgian" to "German" may no longer be necessary. What are your thoughts?

I think it's still worth including the "German" (or any similar word) example as a test case, since it ensures we actually cover the uppercase scenario transparently during the test phase, without allowing any surprises after submitting.

Regarding the link to the pdf, I removed it because it seems to not be working anymore (404),  but feel free to leave it in if you want.

Thank you for replying and clarifying the reason for removing the link.

I've changed the link to credits instead.

I've also inserted a new pair of Test 2 and Validator 2 with short input strings containing both G and g.

I've changed "German" back to "Georgian" in the now Test 5 (previously Test 4), and replaced the original input with a string containing "George" for the now Validator 5 (previously Validator 4).

The changes should ensure better case coverage now.
Nice, good stuff!
I think the five minutes rule has to be checked by coders with some experience, that way beginners have a chance to solve it in 15 min

You could strip any character that is not [azAZ] so the punctuation marks or other are removed. But you end up with another issue related to words such as "Gatsby's" and "Gatsby". But for sure "eggs," can't be considered a valid response.
